conclusion: The problem involves a concealed door lock in a self-locking state where the door cannot be closed despite applying force.
We need to find the normal force between the latch D and the lock groove E when self-locking occurs.
Given parameters include spring stiffness coefficient k, latch inclination angle θ = 30°, dynamic friction coefficient μ, spring compression x, and contact point P.
When self-locking occurs, the system is in static equilibrium despite forces trying to close the door.
Figure B shows the top view of the lock's state with contact point P between latch D and lock groove E.
Forces acting at point P include normal force FN, friction force Ff, spring force Fs = kx, and force components in the sliding door direction.
Self-locking occurs when the friction force is sufficient to prevent movement, i.e., Ff ≥ component of spring force in the sliding direction.
Establishing a coordinate system with x-axis horizontal and y-axis vertical helps analyze force components.
Spring force Fs = kx acts horizontally in the positive x-direction.
Normal force FN acts perpendicular to the inclined surface at angle θ = 30°, with components FN_x = FN·sin(θ) and FN_y = FN·cos(θ).
Friction force Ff = μFN acts along the inclined surface, with components Ff_x = -Ff·sin(θ) and Ff_y = Ff·cos(θ).
Equilibrium in the x-direction requires Fs + FN_x - Ff_x = 0, leading to kx + FN·sin(θ)(1-μ) = 0.
For self-locking in the y-direction, FN_y - Ff_y ≤ 0, leading to FN·cos(θ)(1-μ) ≤ 0, implying μ ≥ 1.
Solving for FN from the x-direction equation gives FN·sin(θ)(1-μ) = -kx.
When self-locking occurs, μ ≥ 1, so (1-μ) ≤ 0, leading to FN = -kx / [sin(θ)(1-μ)].
With θ = 30°, sin(θ) = 0.5, and assuming μ = 1, FN approaches infinity, indicating theoretical self-locking.
For μ > 1, FN = kx / [0.5(μ-1)], leading to FN = 2kx / (μ-1).
The magnitude of the normal force during self-locking is FN = 2kx / (μ-1), depending on spring properties, compression distance, and friction coefficient.
